description: The 5 primitive variables that predict AI organizational structure. These are the independent variables in the theory — everything else (tensions, findings, mechanisms) derives from interactions among these primitives.

primitives.name: Work Architecture Modularity
primitives.definition: The degree to which the organization's core value-creating work can be decomposed into discrete, independently optimizable tasks. Conway's law / Colfer & Baldwin mirroring: organizational structure mirrors technical architecture.

scoringGuide.high: Software-first, API-driven, modular codebase (e.g., Shopify, Stripe)
scoringGuide.medium: Mixed digital/physical, partially modular (e.g., financial services, media)
scoringGuide.low: Integral physical production, tightly coupled systems (e.g., automotive, pharma, manufacturing)

scoringGuide.high: Leader sees work as decomposable tasks, AI slots into task boundaries
scoringGuide.medium: Leader sees some tasks as decomposable, others as integral
scoringGuide.low: Leader sees work as holistic craft requiring integrated judgment

theoreticalAnchors: Baldwin & Clark (2000) — modularity and option value

primitives.name: Work Output Measurability
primitives.definition: The degree to which work quality and outcomes can be captured in quantitative metrics. Holmstrom's multi-task problem: when some dimensions are measurable and others aren't, organizations rationally optimize measurable dimensions while unmeasured dimensions degrade.

scoringGuide.high: Clear quantitative metrics capture most value dimensions (e.g., transaction throughput, code commits)
scoringGuide.medium: Partial measurability — some dimensions captured, others tacit (e.g., customer service quality, investment judgment)
scoringGuide.low: Key quality dimensions resist quantification (e.g., clinical judgment, creative quality, institutional knowledge)

scoringGuide.high: AI deployment metrics accurately reflect total value creation
scoringGuide.medium: Metrics capture efficiency gains but miss some quality dimensions
scoringGuide.low: Metrics systematically overstate AI success — unmeasured quality degradation invisible

primitives.name: Governance Structure
primitives.definition: The allocation of formal and real authority over AI structural decisions, and the incentive contracts (explicit and implicit) that shape how that authority is exercised. Not just 'who is the CEO' but the full governance regime: residual claimancy, board composition, shareholder base, formal vs. real authority gaps.

scoringGuide.high: Founder-CEO with significant equity stake — personal wealth tied to long-term firm value
scoringGuide.medium: Hired CEO with strong board backing, moderate tenure security
scoringGuide.low: Hired CEO facing activist pressure, short tenure expectation, or government mandate-driven role

scoringGuide.high: AI decision-maker has both formal title AND domain expertise/organizational influence
scoringGuide.medium: Partial alignment — formal authority in some domains, real authority in others
scoringGuide.low: Significant gap — AI leader has title but lacks domain credibility or organizational influence (e.g., CAIO without manufacturing expertise)

scoringGuide.high: Supportive long-term investors, aligned board, minimal activist pressure
scoringGuide.medium: Mixed shareholder base, board broadly supportive but quarterly-conscious
scoringGuide.low: Active short-term pressure, activist investors, ESG mandates constraining AI choices

theoreticalAnchors: Aghion & Tirole (1997) — formal vs. real authority
Gibbons (2005) — four theories of the firm

primitives.name: Competitive and Institutional Context
primitives.definition: The external forces — competitive dynamics, regulatory environment, labor market structure, industry norms — that shape the returns to different structural choices. NOT sociological 'environmental pull' but economic competitive and institutional forces.

scoringGuide.high: AI-native entrants threatening core business, winner-take-all race dynamics
scoringGuide.medium: Rivals deploying AI as competitive tool, but not existential threat
scoringGuide.low: Low AI competitive pressure, stable market positions, AI as efficiency tool not strategic weapon

scoringGuide.high: Heavy regulation requiring audit trails, review processes, explainability (pharma, finance, healthcare)
scoringGuide.medium: Moderate regulatory requirements, professional norms constrain some applications
scoringGuide.low: Light regulation, few institutional constraints on AI deployment

primitives.name: Organizational Endowment
primitives.definition: The inherited organizational characteristics that constrain the feasible set of AI structural choices independent of current strategy. Path-dependent endowments that cannot be changed quickly.

scoringGuide.high: Cloud-native, modern data infrastructure, API-first architecture
scoringGuide.medium: Partial modernization, some legacy systems, data infrastructure improving
scoringGuide.low: Heavy legacy systems, fragmented data, requires multi-year infrastructure transformation before AI deployment

scoringGuide.high: Loosely coupled divisional structure — can spin up independent AI units without disrupting core
scoringGuide.medium: Mixed — some divisions independent, some tightly integrated
scoringGuide.low: Tightly coupled functional structure — AI exploration units would disrupt core coordination (e.g., Apple)

scoringGuide.medium: Mixed — some physical infrastructure, some digital
scoringGuide.low: Capital-intensive — manufacturing, logistics, energy, physical infrastructure constrains toward embedded models

scoringGuide.high: Can attract frontier AI researchers — brand, location, compensation, mission appeal
scoringGuide.medium: Competitive for applied AI talent but not frontier researchers
scoringGuide.low: Talent-constrained — defaults to partnerships, vendor solutions, or domain-expert reskilling
